Amazon and Google could get some tough competition from Apple in the smart speaker segment.¬†Apple is reportedly developing a smart speaker, similar to that of Amazon Echo and Google Home. The leak comes from prolific tipster Sonny Dickson. ‚ÄúApple is currently finalizing designs for their Apple competitor, expected to be marketed as a Siri/AirPlay device‚Äù, Dickson said on Twitter. Apple is currently finalising designs for their Alexa competitor, expected to be marketed as a Siri/AirPlay device. ‚Äî Sonny Dickson (@SonnyDickson) April 27, 2017 He later added:¬†‚ÄúIt is believed to carry some form of Beats technology, and is expected to run an variant iOS‚Äù. Dickson told Mashable‚Äôs Jen Ryall that the smart speaker will sport a design that‚Äôs inspired by the Mac Pro, and the UE Boom‚Äôs mesh styling. ¬†Dickson did not mention anything about a release date for the device, or a price. He however believes that Apple could launch the device at this year‚Äôs WWDC. More from @SonnyDickson on Apple‚Äôs Alexa competitor. ‚Äì Concave top with the controls, fat with the speaker mesh portion covering it all. 1/2 ‚Äî Jen Ryall (@jennijenni) April 28, 2017 AirPlay functionality in the upcoming in the Siri-powered speaker has been reported before, alongside a Siri DK release, notes 9to5Mac. However, the surprising part is that speaker speaker will include ‚ÄúBeats technology‚Äù. It‚Äôs being said that Apple might add Beat‚Äôs audio tech into its own smart speaker system. This is not the first time we‚Äôre hearing that Apple is developing a smart speaker. Back in May 2016, The Information reported that Apple¬†could launch an ‚ÄúAmazon Eco-like device with a speaker and microphone built-in‚Äù. At that time, it was suggested that the device could be launched at the company‚Äôs annual WWDC. Two months later, CNET reported that Apple‚Äôs Siri-powered speaker would be ‚Äúself-aware‚Äù abd able to detect the people who are in close proximity to the device using ‚Äúon-board‚Äù cameras equipped with some sort of facial recognition software. In February 2017, however, ¬†Times‚Äôs Tim Bajarin said that Apple was no longer interested in developing an intelligent speaker. Instead, Apple is ‚Äúmore interested in turning Siri into an omnipresent AI assistant across devices, rather than designing a single device specifically to serve as a Siri machine‚Äù. Amazon‚Äôs Echo is perhaps the most popular voice-based smart speaker on the market today. Earlier in the week, the company revealed its latest Echo device, the Echo Look that comes with a built-in cameras. Amazon‚Äôs Echo devices are powered by the company‚Äôs Alexa assistant. Economy Federal Reserve Capitol Report Economic Report Columns Darrell Delamaide Irwin Kellner Rex Nutting Tools Economic Calendar Real Estate Location Scouts realtor.com My MarketWatch Watchlist Alerts Games Log In Home Industries Internet/Online Services Google‚Äôs Sundar Pichai is likely the highest-paid CEO By Jeremy C. Owens Published: Apr 29, 2017 4:31 p.m. ET Share Head of Alphabet‚Äôs largest division made nearly $200 million in 2016, twice as much as any CEO tracked in the past two years Getty Images Google Chief Executive Sundar Pichai received $199.7 million in total compensation in 2016, Alphabet reported Friday. By JeremyC. Owens Technology Editor Alphabet Inc. awarded Google Chief Executive Sundar Pichai nearly $200 million in total compensation in 2016, more than twice as much as any CEO of a publicly traded company tracked in the last two years. In its annual proxy statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission, filed Friday, Alphabet GOOGL, +3.71% GOOG, +3.63% revealed that Pichai was awarded $198.7 million in Alphabet stock in 2016. That is roughly double the stock Pichai received in 2015, when he was named chief executive of Google after the company reorganized as Alphabet. Don‚Äôt miss: 5 things to know about Google CEO Sundar Pichai Along with a $650,000 salary and $372,000 in recognized compensation in the form of personal security and flights, Pichai received total compensation of $199.7 million in 2016. That was nearly double his 2015 total compensation of $100.7 million. Pichai‚Äôs total compensation tops the CEO compensation packages tracked by Equilar for the past two years. In 2015, Dara Khosrowshahi of Expedia Inc. EXPE, -1.82% had the highest compensation among CEOs of publicly traded companies, at $94.6 million, according to Equilar‚Äôs annual study. Among proxy statements filed before April 1, Equilar found Thomas Rutledge of Charter Communications Inc. CHTR, -1.04% was the highest-paid CEO for 2016, at more than $98 million. Pichai, though, would not show up on Equilar‚Äôs list because he is not the CEO of a publicly traded company, but rather of the Google subsidiary within Alphabet. Alphabet CEO Larry Page is the executive who would show up in Equilar‚Äôs annual study, and Page‚Äîalong with fellow Google founder and Alphabet President Sergey Brin‚Äîaccepted only $1 in annual salary and no stock compensation, according to the filing. Equilar spokesman Dan Marcec confirmed that Pichai was not included in the firm‚Äôs annual CEO-compensation study because of the quirks of Alphabet‚Äôs corporate structure. He said Pichai is ‚Äúprobably‚Äù the highest-paid top executive in the land. See also: The CEO of your company probably earns 276 times more than you do Equilar reported earlier this month that the early returns from its annual effort showed CEO pay on the rise, with median CEO compensation up 6% to $15 million and average compensation increasing from $15.5 million to $16.6 million. It is the largest increase tracked since 2013. Pichai received a $199 million equity award upon his promotion, Alphabet disclosed last year, and this year‚Äôs filing showed an additional $209 million biennial equity award issued in early 2016 that vests quarterly. The completion of the first award and beginning of the second appeared to lead to Pichai‚Äôs large total compensation for 2016. Other key Google execs fell between the Pichai and Page extremes: Diane Greene, who was hired to run Google‚Äôs cloud business late in 2015, received total compensation of $43.7 million in 2016, and Chief Financial Officer Ruth Porat received total compensation of slightly more than $39 million. Such large compensation awards are not unheard of among executives at large tech companies, especially when they receive big stock awards upon being hired or promoted. For instance, Tim Cook was handed a $378 million stock award when he was named CEO of Apple Inc. AAPL, -0.10% in 2011, making him the highest paid CEO that year. Last year, Cook‚Äôs total compensation took a hit, falling to $8.75 million from $10.28 million the year before, but he still has a massive cache of Apple shares. Since Google reorganized as Alphabet and made Pichai CEO of the Google division, Google stock has gained 39.1%, while the S&P 500 index SPX, -0.19% has risen about 14.8% over that period. The stock hit fresh record highs Friday after Alphabet beat earnings expectations, and Alphabet is the only company besides Apple with a market capitalization of more than $600 billion. More from MarketWatch Why Trump Gets a 100-Day Review ‚Äî When Others Don‚Äôt Trump's Tax Plan: Three Key Takeaways Google‚Äôs Sundar Pichai is likely the highest-paid CEO Quote References GOOGL +33.08 +3.71% GOOG +31.71 +3.63% EXPE -2.48 -1.82% CHTR -3.64 -1.04% AAPL -0.14 -0.10% SPX -4.57 -0.19% Show all references Most Popular Elizabeth Warren says Obama got it wrong: It‚Äôs worse than Americans realize Elon Musk: Self-driving Teslas will go between LA and NYC by the end of the year It‚Äôs harder than you think to spend down your 401(k) account in retirement 5 doomed stocks to sell in May French Election: Who Is Marine Le Pen? Here's a parody that will make you avoid the originals Vinod Khanna, a bar of soap, a saddle-free horse, and 1980s advertising cool Sections Opinion Politics Culture India World Film and TV Music Books and Ideas Business and Economy Science and Technology Subscribe to Mailers Feedback Get the Android app Blog About Readers' Editor Letters to the Editor Our tech Jobs Terms of use Privacy Policy Yesterday ¬∑ 04:10 pm. ¬† Scroll Staff Share Tweet Email Reddit Print Share Tweet Email Reddit Print Business News Google‚Äôs Sundar Pichai received almost $200 million as compensation in 2016 Alphabet, Google‚Äôs parent company, attributed the numbers to the Indian-born executive‚Äôs ‚Äònumerous successful product launches‚Äô. Scroll Staff Published Yesterday ¬∑ 04:10 pm. ¬† Wikimedia Commons Google Chief Executive Officer Sundar Pichai received almost $200 million (approximately Rs 1,285 crore) as a compensation package in 2016. The company attributed it to the Indian-born executive‚Äôs ‚Äúnumerous successful product launches‚Äù, CNN reported. A majority of the remuneration was in company stock, whose value is estimated to be around $198.7 million in securities documents. Pichai was granted the package a few months after he took over the position in 2015 from Google co-founder Larry Page, who received $1 as annual pay. Page has an estimated fortune of $41 billion. Pichai still reports to Page under the restructured management. The 44-year-old Pichai also received a $6,50,000 salary in 2016 excluding the personal security services and air travel valued provided at an estimated $3,72,000, AP reported. Google‚Äôs sales from its core advertising and YouTube business has been on the rise under Pichai‚Äôs leadership. The company has also invested in machine learning, hardware and cloud computing since he took over. We welcome your comments at letters@scroll.in. Sundar Pichai Google Alphabet Larry Page Print Related Brexit impact: Most CEOs in UK are considering shifting operations abroad, finds KPMG survey Trending Hyderabad‚Äôs Human Library treats humans as books that can be ‚Äòborrowed‚Äô for 30 minutes They paid a price for Adityanath's hate speech ‚Äì and now have fallen silent This map shows just how alarming Tamil Nadu‚Äôs water crisis is A night at India‚Äôs first capsule hotel shows that Mumbai‚Äôs space crunch is now a hospitality fad Eight mistakes I made as the mother of a child with autism Sponsored Content¬† BY¬† These GIFs show you what it means to miss breakfast That monstrous roar is your empty stomach. Published Apr 27, 2017. ¬† Imgflip Apr 27, 2017. ¬† Share Tweet Email Reddit Print Share Tweet Email Reddit Print Let‚Äôs take a glance at your every day morning routine. You crawl out of bed, go for a quick shower, pull out and wear your neatly ironed clothes at the speed of light and then rush out of the house, making sure you have your keys and wallet in place. Giphy You walk into office, relieved because you have made it to work on time. Stifling yawns and checking emails, you wonder how your colleagues are charged up and buzzing with energy. ‚ÄúWhat is wrong with these people‚Äù you mumble to yourself. Giphy Slowly, you start to change. You start snapping at colleagues and start arguing with your computer. You take out your frustration on anything or anyone in sight. To add to the aggressive behaviour, you‚Äôve completely lost your focus. After some time, you simply forget what you were doing. Giphy Unable to bear the hunger pangs, you go for a mid-morning snack. It is only when a colleague asks you for a bite do you realize that you have developed into a fully formed, hunger fueled, monster. Try not to look at yourself in the mirror. Giphy If only you had spared not even twenty or ten but just 5 minutes in the morning and not skipped breakfast, your story would look completely different - as you will see in this video. Play The fast dip in your mood and lack of focus is because your body has missed its most important meal of the day ‚Äì breakfast. Research has shown that skipping a meal, especially in the morning, worsens the mood because there is a drop in the blood sugar. This in turn affects the levels of serotonin and dopamine, the chemicals produced in the brain that control our moods and feelings. In simpler English, not having breakfast is going to make you really cranky and confused! Morning is also when the body needs maximum nutrition to function efficiently through the day as you‚Äôve just woken up from a full 7 hours of no food (and if you‚Äôre sleeping less than that, that‚Äôs a whole other article). So in short, having a breakfast could make you go from looking like the earlier GIFs to this: Giphy But with changing lifestyles and most people hard pressed for time, a healthy breakfast is taking the backseat. However, it doesn‚Äôt have to be that way. MTR has come up with a range of widely loved Indian delicacies like Poha, Upma and Halwa which can be made in (hold you breath) just 3 minutes! All you have to do is add hot water and wait for 3 minutes to get a delicious and filling breakfast. Giphy These amazing and delicious breakfasts can be made in a jiffy and consumed with the least hassle, even in the midst of your frenetic morning routine. So grab your #MTRbreakfastin3 to start the day on an awesome note. Click here to make breakfast a part of your morning routine. What We Use, 2017 Edition: The stuff Corbin can't live without Corbin Davenport Follow View All Posts 2017/04/28 8:26am PDTApr 28, 2017 11 Plus 1 on G+ 20 Share on Facebook 42 Share on Twitter Total Shares73 Features What We Use Series Article Contents 1 Hardware 1.0.1 Phone: Google Pixel 1.0.2 Tablet: Samsung Galaxy Tab S 8.4 1.0.3 Desktop PC: 'Enterprise' 1.0.4 Laptop: Dell Latitude 3340 ('Defiant') 1.0.5 Smartwatch: Huawei Watch (1st generation) 1.0.6 Camera: Sony Alpha a5000 1.0.7 Smart speaker: Google Home 1.0.8 Microphone: Blue Snowball iCE 1.0.9 Webcam: Logitech HD Pro C920 1.0.10 Charging dock: iKits 10-Port charging dock 2 Software 2.0.1 Sublime Text (Windows/Mac/Linux) 2.0.2 Signal Spy (Android) 2.0.3 InputMapper (Windows) 2.0.4 Chrome extensions (Windows/Mac/Linux) 3 Conclusion You may recall Android Police's long-running 'What We Use' series, where the fantastic people that work here share the tech (and sometimes non-tech) products they use on a frequent basis. I haven't actually written one of these posts yet - simply because I only joined AP last year.¬†I've had a fascination with technology as long as I can remember, but¬†my¬†arsenal of toys¬†is constantly changing. So without further ado, this is what I use. Hardware Phone: Google Pixel You may recall from my introduction post that¬†I was using a Nexus 5X. At the time, it was definitely the best phone I had ever used. The build quality was decent, but it was more than fast enough for my needs, the front-facing speakers were fantastic, and the camera was amazing. But all good things come to an end, and my 5X suffered the famous bootlooping bug that so many other 5X owners have¬†experienced. Being on Project Fi, and not really wanting to switch, I coughed up the money for a 32GB 5" Pixel. And while it has certainly been a great device and I would definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a fantastic Android phone, I still think it's overpriced. For those interested, I'm using the Unicorn Beetle Pro case. In addition to the Pixel, I also own a Microsoft Lumia 550 running Windows 10 Mobile. I bought it a few months before my 5X died (mostly to play around with Windows 10 Mobile), and it ended up being¬†my daily driver for roughly two weeks while I waited for my Pixel to ship. The lack of any Google services - especially Hangouts - means I can't really use it in place of an Android phone. But it does work just fine as a backup two-factor authentication device. Tablet: Samsung Galaxy Tab S 8.4 Most mainstream Android tablets hover around 9-10 inches, such as the Pixel C, the Tab S3, and the ASUS ZenPad I reviewed a while back. But I prefer 8.0-8.5"¬†tablets, leaving me with few options that weren't outdated. Currently, I'm using a Samsung Galaxy Tab S 8.4, and it's pretty great for what I need. Samsung has yet to update this to Nougat (and it will probably be a while), so I flashed LineageOS 14.1 on it. The Exynos 5420 processor does slow down occasionally, usually while multi-tasking or trying to play 1080p YouTube videos, but it's still plenty fast for most tasks. The Google Play Movies and Netflix apps don't play video at HD though - I assume because of some DRM restriction with Lineage. Desktop PC: 'Enterprise' My current desktop computer is my first custom-built PC, named 'Enterprise' (I name all of my computers after ships from Star Trek). It has an AMD Athlon X4 860k processor, Gigabyte GA-F2A68HM-H MicroATX motherboard, 420W EVGA power supply, and 16GB of RAM. I've recently upgraded my graphics card to an XFX Radeon RX 470. For storage, I have a 256GB boot SSD and a 1TB hard drive for storing games and backups. As for the rest of my setup, I'm using a simple Dell USB keyboard¬†with a Logitech G402 mouse. The keyboard is pretty nice, despite the low cost, and the mouse is quite comfortable.¬†I've just replaced my previous¬†dual-monitor setup (consisting of an old 1080p display and an ancient VGA monitor) with a¬†Dell U2913WM ultra-wide panel,¬†which has been fantastic so far. Seriously, playing games at ultrawide is amazing. Since originally building it last year, I've swapped out the original case for the¬†APEVIA X-QBER White enclosure, seen in the above picture. I'm not a fan of the windows, but I love that the case can flip open for easy access. Laptop: Dell Latitude 3340 ('Defiant') Before I decided to build my first computer (the PC in the last section), I had a Surface Pro 2 as my workstation. The concept of having one device to serve as my tablet, laptop, and desktop PC seemed great. I didn't even mind that it was a bit heavy - but I did mind the battery life. I'm not sure if it was Windows, the battery capacity, or the fact that I bought it used, but the Pro 2¬†would barely last a few hours on most days. I sold the Surface less than a year after I initially bought it, and decided to go with a normal boring laptop. My priorities were battery life, the ability to be upgraded, and durability - things my Surface Pro weren't very good at. I eventually stumbled upon a Dell Latitude 3340 for $200 on eBay, with a 13.3" 1366x768 display and a Core i5-4200U. Being a laptop designed for use in schools, it was pretty durable and almost every component could be replaced. I bought it, and spent another $100 swapping out the hard drive for a Samsung Evo 850 SSD and upgrading the RAM to 12GB. I also put a Stormtrooper decal on the back, because every laptop needs stickers. In short, I'm pretty happy with it. The laptop isn't thin by any means, but the battery life is solid and it's plenty fast for my needs. And after I replaced the spinning hard disk with an SSD, it has become dead silent (except during intense workloads). The resolution isn't great, but that's really my only complaint. Smartwatch: Huawei Watch (1st generation) Unlike some of the other writers here at Android Police, I still like the idea of smartwatches. I was an early adopter of Android Wear, and I loved diving into the underlying Android system. I bought a refurbished Huawei Watch a few months ago to replace my¬†original LG G Watch. I also own a first-gen Moto 360, which has unfortunately stopped working, and a Gear Live that needs a new watchband. Besides being a little thicker than I would like, the Huawei Watch is definitely a great¬†device. I don't really care that it's missing NFC or LTE, but I wouldn't mind the digital crown that some of the newer Android Wear watches have. Camera: Sony Alpha a5000 I know as much about cameras as I do cars - that is to say, not very much. Until I started working for AP, I had only used smartphones and sub-$50 digital cameras to take photos. So I consulted David to help pick a new camera, and I ended up with the Sony Alpha a5000. I've only had this camera for about a week, so I can't say much about it yet. It takes pictures. The a5000's Wi-Fi and NFC connectivity is especially cool - I can tap the camera to my Pixel and instantly transfer photos (which are then backed up to Google Photos). The Wi-Fi connectivity also allows me to remotely take photos with my phone as the viewfinder. I've used this several times already to take pictures of birds flying up to a nearby bird feeder. All of the photos in this post (except the picture of the camera) were taken on the a5000, so feel free to rage about my lack of photography skills leave constructive feedback in the comment section. Smart speaker: Google Home I initially bought a Google Home shortly after it was released, to replace an old set of iPod speakers I was using with a Chromecast Audio. I primarily use the Home as a wireless speaker, and it's pretty good at that. I don't really care for most smart home products, but I did buy¬†two WeMo¬†Smart Plugs on sale so I could control¬†two lamps in my room. Initially, these only worked through Google Assistant's IFTTT integration, but Google added native support for WeMo products a few months ago. I'll admit, the Google Home still seems half-baked. Most of my complaints about it from January are still valid, especially not being able to set reminders. I used the shopping list feature quite a bit, but Google basically ruined that. Microphone: Blue Snowball iCE I've been on the Android Police podcast for a while now, on a somewhat-infrequent basis (usually due to technical issues). My $11 headset I use for games wasn't really going to cut it, so I bought the Blue Snowball iCE condenser microphone. Overall, I'm pretty happy with it for the price.¬†The quality is very good and it's fairly portable. However, the microphone does occasionally disappear from Windows (I'm pretty sure that's Windows' fault), and the red light on the front is rather bright. As you can see in the above picture, I covered that up with some duct tape. Webcam: Logitech HD Pro C920 Another item I bought primarily for the AP Podcast was a webcam - Logitech's HD Pro C920 camera. In most cases, video calling is limited to 720p, but it can record and take photos at 1080p. Supposedly it works at 1080p with Skype for Windows, but I haven't tested that. Sample shot with the HD Pro C920. I don't really have any complaints about this webcam. It does webcam things. Charging dock: iKits 10-Port charging dock I have a ton of electronics that charge over USB. So a few months ago, I tried to become a bit more organized and replace my mess of charging adapters and cables with a single dock. After looking at a few on Amazon, I settled on iKit's 10-port charging dock. And it's seriously awesome. As you can see in the above picture, it has six normal 5V1A ports and four 5V2.4A ports.¬†With this, I can charge my tablet, phones, camera, and even my Nintendo DSi and 3DS (with this¬†cable).¬†The primary advantage is that the dock only needs one two-prong outlet, so you don't have to use separate wall adapters for every single device. If you have a bunch of products¬†that charge over USB, I definitely recommend this (or another dock like it). Software Most of the apps and programs I use on a daily basis are pretty popular. Chrome for browsing the web, Google Photos for image backups, Photoshop CS6 for photo editing, etc. That being said, there are a few apps/programs I use that you may not have heard of. Sublime Text (Windows/Mac/Linux) Sublime Text has been my main text editor for a few years now. Unlike Atom Editor and Visual Studio Code, it doesn't run inside a web shell, but still has plenty of plugins and themes. It supports auto-complete and syntax highlighting for dozens of languages,¬†so it's pretty versatile. I primarily use it when I'm working on Chrome extensions and Python scripts, and I don't think I've ever had a single problem. You can buy it for $70 from Sublime's site - the license works across platforms. Signal Spy (Android) ¬†¬† This is a pretty cool utility for Android, available on the Play Store for free (with a pro version available). It gives you information about the¬†carrier you are connected to, including the band being used and your signal strength. It also provides data about your Wi-Fi connection. If you're on Project Fi, as I am, Signal Spy has some extra functionality. As you may know, Project Fi switches between T-Mobile/US Cellular/Sprint based on who has the best signal. Occasionally, the switching algorithm doesn't work and leaves you with a poor connection. With Signal Spy, you can easily force a connection to a specific carrier (or re-enable auto switching). InputMapper (Windows) There are a few PC games that I use a controller for, such as Grand Theft Auto V. I actually prefer Sony's DualShock 4 controller over the Xbox 360 or Xbox One controllers, but very few PC games natively support the DS4. That's where InputMapper comes in. InputMapper is a small free utility that allows you to use a DualShock 4 controller with any game that supports Xbox controllers. It does this by emulating an Xinput device, and all the input from the DS4 is sent to the emulated controller. There is no loss in functionality, and you can use a DS4 over Bluetooth or USB. You can even remap buttons, as seen in the above screenshot. Chrome extensions (Windows/Mac/Linux) Lastly, I wanted to include a few Chrome extensions that I have found¬†extremely useful. Some of these are available on other browsers too. HTTPS Everywhere: This is an extension developed by the EFF that forces HTTPS on sites known to support it. Keepa: This adds a price history chart to Amazon listings. Privacy Badger: This is another extension from the EFF, which tries to block trackers online. Sometimes it can break certain sites, so if a web page won't work right for some reason, you probably need to turn this extension off. Peek: If you hover over a link to a file (or Google Doc), it will show a preview of it. It supports videos, audio files, PDFs, Office documents, and more. Full disclosure - I developed this one, but I think it's pretty darn useful. Save Image as PNG:¬†This adds a 'Save image as PNG' item to the right-click menu. Pretty simple. Toolbox for Google Play Store: This adds a few cool features to the Play Store web site, like a button on app listings to see APKs on APKMirror. It's actually developed by Android Police! Conclusion Wow, this post was long. If you¬†have any questions about the hardware or software in this list, feel free to ask me in the comments below. (Reuters) SYDNEY: Alphabet Inc.‚Äôs Google said it would challenge amended tax assessments issued by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO), which is trying to claw back billions of dollars from multinational corporations citing unpaid taxes. The ATO has increased scrutiny over how much tax multinationals operating in Australia pay. In December, it said it was pursuing seven global businesses over AU$2 billion ($1.50 billion) in unpaid tax. While the ATO has not named the businesses it is pursuing, Google‚Äôs Australia unit said in accounts filed with the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) that it will ‚Äúlodge an objection‚Äù to the tax demand from the ATO. ‚ÄúThe company will continue to uphold its positions against any and all such claims,‚Äù Google said in the financial statement released on Friday. The search giant did not disclose how much the ATO has demanded it pay in taxes. Google and the ATO declined to comment on how much the company‚Äôs amended tax bill was. Treasurer Scott Morrison said in April the country expected to claw back AU$2.9 billion from companies under the legislation. Australia enacted the Multinational Anti-Avoidance Law in December 2015 and the ATO has introduced new guidelines for foreign trading hubs. Google Australia restructured its operations effective Jan. 1 of last year to comply with the legislation and its financial statement reveals an increase in revenue and tax for the 2016 calendar year as a result. Revenue surged to AU$1.14 billion in 2016 from AU$498 million in 2015, while total income tax rose to AU$16 million from AU$2.8 million in 2015, the accounts show. SYDNEY: Alphabet Inc.‚Äôs Google said it would challenge amended tax assessments issued by the Australian Taxation Office (ATO), which is trying to claw back billions of dollars from multinational corporations citing unpaid taxes. The ATO has increased scrutiny over how much tax multinationals operating in Australia pay. In December, it said it was pursuing seven global businesses over AU$2 billion ($1.50 billion) in unpaid tax. While the ATO has not named the businesses it is pursuing, Google‚Äôs Australia unit said in accounts filed with the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) that it will ‚Äúlodge an objection‚Äù to the tax demand from the ATO. ‚ÄúThe company will continue to uphold its positions against any and all such claims,‚Äù Google said in the financial statement released on Friday. The search giant did not disclose how much the ATO has demanded it pay in taxes. Google and the ATO declined to comment on how much the company‚Äôs amended tax bill was. Treasurer Scott Morrison said in April the country expected to claw back AU$2.9 billion from companies under the legislation. Australia enacted the Multinational Anti-Avoidance Law in December 2015 and the ATO has introduced new guidelines for foreign trading hubs. Google Australia restructured its operations effective Jan. 1 of last year to comply with the legislation and its financial statement reveals an increase in revenue and tax for the 2016 calendar year as a result. Revenue surged to AU$1.14 billion in 2016 from AU$498 million in 2015, while total income tax rose to AU$16 million from AU$2.8 million in 2015, the accounts show. Home On Campus Alumni Athletics Campus News Greek Spotlight Features Food Tech World Entertainment Anime Comics Movies & Music Video Games Opinion Editorials Food for Thought Op-Ed About Contact Search for: HomeGeneral NewsGoogle and the Gender Pay Gap-Searching for Answers¬† Google and the Gender Pay Gap-Searching for Answers¬† April 29, 2017 Karen Ayoub General News 0 Just last week, Google was accused by the federal government for paying its female employees significantly less. The idea of a ‚Äúgender pay gap‚Äù has caused much controversy over the past decade. According to Google Books‚Äô Ngram Viewer, which shows trends in the usage of specific words or phrases in books, the usage of ‚Äúgender pay gap‚Äù has steadily been increasing since 1980. Of course, this only reflects the phrase‚Äôs occurrence in books, whether in print or online. However, it does not encompass every news article, blog post, Facebook status, tweet, etc. How ironic it is that Google is the one under accusation of contributing to this gender pay gap? On Friday, April 7, a court hearing took place. In a report published by The Guardian, U.S. Department of Labor regional director, Janette Wipper, revealed the official allegations against Google: ‚ÄúWe found systemic compensation disparities against women pretty much across [Google‚Äôs] entire workforce.‚Äù However, Google denied these statements, saying that there was no gender pay gap between their male and female employees. Eileen Naughton, Google‚Äôs Vice President of People Operations, testified regarding Google‚Äôs pay equality, citing Google‚Äôs annual salary analysis that is ‚Äúextremely scientific and robust‚Äù and ‚Äúgender blind.‚Äù It seems as though either Google or the feds are wrong, but could it be possible that both sides of the argument are ‚Äì to an extent ‚Äì true? According to an analysis by Dr. Andrew Chamberlain, the chief economist of Glassdoor, a site where employees can rate companies and management, this could actually be the case. On Glassdoor, employees self-reported their salaries, and Chamberlain examined these for Google employees. Although this data did not encompass all of Google‚Äôs employees, it served as a good sample size for the company. Chamberlain‚Äôs findings were quite interesting. According to Chamberlain‚Äôs findings, overall, Google pays women 16 percent less than it pays men. On the surface, this may seem disturbing ‚Äì but that is not the entire picture. Fewer women work in high-ranking positions at Google relative to the number of men working in those positions. Chamberlain says, ‚ÄúIn our sample of Google salaries, men and women are definitely not equally represented among job titles. For example, about 52 percent of males in our data worked as highly paid software engineers, while just 21 percent of women worked in those roles. By contrast, 6 percent of women in the sample worked as product marketing managers, while just 2 percent of men worked in those roles.‚Äù This is a concept known as ‚Äúoccupational segregation.‚Äù Although men and women may be paid the same across one position, just the fact that there may be more men in higher paying jobs contributes at least 54 percent to the gender pay gap according to Chamberlain‚Äôs research. In fact, this situation is not unique to Google; it is characteristic of many other technology companies. From this lawsuit, it is clear that the idea of the ‚Äúgender pay gap‚Äù in America needs to be reexamined. RecomN - Local Services|¬†About Us|¬†E-Paper|¬†Search|¬†MOBILE KLIK UNTUK PROJEKMMO ÁÇπÂáªM‰∏≠ÊñáÁΩë Facebook Twitter RSS Last updated Sunday, April 30, 2017 2:58 pm GMT+8 Kuala Lumpur 33¬∞C, Mostly Cloudy MMOTV News Malaysia World Money Life Showbiz Opinion Sports Eat/Drink Travel Read Tech/Gadgets Drive Gallery Life Google ties up with Singapore‚Äôs JustRunLah! to offer street views of popular running trails Sunday April 30, 2017 09:47 AM GMT+8 ICYMI The Edit: New ‚ÄòOrange is the New Black‚Äô leaked by hacker The Edit: Five fave spots for Hakka noodles in KL and PJ Trump celebrates first 100 days as president, blasts media (VIDEO) Mladenovic ends Sharapova‚Äôs doping comeback in Stuttgart Advertisement More stories ¬†¬† ¬†¬† ¬†¬† ¬†¬† ¬†¬† Tools Increase Text Decrease Text Reset Text Print Article JustRunLah! community members Paviter Singh (left) and Ben Flint don the Street View trekkers at Mount Faber Park April 27, 2017. ‚Äî TODAY picSINGAPORE, April 30 ‚Äî Singaporeans and tourists alike will soon be able explore 360Àö panoramic views of popular running trails in Singapore ‚Äî all from the comfort of their mobile phones or computers. Search giant Google in Singapore has tied up from local running group JustRunLah! to capture photographs of popular running routes like Singapore Botanic Gardens, Mount Faber Park and MacRitchie Reservoir, among others. The group aims to cover more than 30 running routes spanning over 400km in the next few months. They plan to cover one on a ‚Äútwo-to-three week‚Äù basis after undergoing training sessions with the Google team, said Peter Tan, Managing Director, JustRunLah!, who also runs an online lifestyle and community site targeted at runners. As a running enthusiast himself, he hopes the project will encourage more people to lead an active lifestyle, as well as allow runners to plan their treks ahead of time. ‚ÄúUtimately, if you are not very familiar with the place and have not done any research, there‚Äôs a possibility you may turn a wrong one... With this project, I hope there‚Äôs the possibility of better planning. Anyone with a smartphone will see their route going forward, and if there‚Äôs any chance of getting lost, you can make your way back as well,‚Äù said Tan. Members of the group will take turns to don Google‚Äôs Street View trekker ‚Äî a 20kg and 1.2m tall ‚Äúwearable backpack‚Äù ‚Äî as they traverse around the island‚Äôs running routes. The Street View trekker has 15 cameras mounted at the top for 360Àö panoramic imagery. Only two sets are currently available in Singapore, and one will be loaned to JustRunLah!. On Thursday, members of the group, including Tan, had their first go at the trekker while walking on the Marang trail at Mount Faber. Because of the size and weight of the equipment, individuals using the trekker have been advised not to run for safety reasons, and also to capture the images of best quality. According to Google, roughly one in five searches on their search engine are location-related, especially searches from mobile devices. More than a third of mobile queries are related to location, the company said. ‚ÄúWe can see that location clearly matters to people, and so it‚Äôs our goal to provide the most comprehensive, accurate and easy-to-use maps and make them accessible to as many people as possible,‚Äù said Cynthia Wei, Street View Programme Manager, APAC. Users who are interested to contribute to Street View can download the app on the Google Play and iOS app store. ‚Äî TODAY ¬†¬† ¬†¬† ¬†¬† ¬†¬† ¬†¬† MORE ON MMOTV Most Viewed Now Week Morocco‚Äôs Christian converts emerge from the shadows Google ties up with Singapore‚Äôs JustRunLah! to offer street views of popular running trails Chaos-hit ‚ÄòCoachella for the super rich‚Äô promises refunds ‚Äî and comeback (VIDEO) Tabiyo Shop: A place for designer notebooks and stationery... in Seremban! Menu About Information Operations Holistic¬†Organizers IO, Cyber, SC, PD Community¬†Calendar Name and Shame, Educating the¬†Media Fake News ¬∑ Information Warfare Alt-News, Fake News, Russian Propaganda and Russian Proxy Websites Under Increased Scrutiny and¬†Crackdown April 29, 2017 Joel Harding I read this article on RINF.com with interest, Google now threatening Alt-News¬†web-sites. ¬†Apparently, the crackdown on fake news is directly impacting what is also called the ‚ÄúAlternative News‚Äù or alt-news community. That is good news, in my opinion. One of my favorite ‚Äòalternative‚Äô journalists, an American working in East Ukraine, highlighted the article. ‚ÄúHe‚Äù is published almost exclusively on those sites. ¬†I put ‚Äúhe‚Äù in quotation marks because some of my Ukrainian friends believe he is a she. There is no record of his name in Ukraine. The article points out that Google is removing articles from these fake news sites. As they say in the article: ‚ÄúGoogle have an agenda.‚Äù Seeing as they‚Äôre professional journalists, it should be ‚ÄúGoogle HAS an agenda‚Äù. ¬†But it is true, Google, Facebook, and other social media websites are aggressively removing these trash sites from the internet. In the article, there is a list of alt-news sites for me to balance against my¬†Russian News And Russian Proxy News Sites and Conspiracy Theory¬†Sites. ¬†RINF is a new one, most of the rest I recognize. I believe it was Zerohedge that threw a conniption for being labeled a fake-news site last year‚Ä¶ RINF.com washingtonsblog.com globalresearch.ca zerohedge.com sott.netoff-guardian.org strategic-culture.org countercurrents.org greanvillepost.com thepeoplesvoice.org The good news is that Google and others are aggressively policing up the crap sites which post junk on the internet. Junk, fake news, alternative news, alt-news. It‚Äôs about time. Thank you, Google and Facebook! [Deal Alert] Pixel 32GB (international version) is $50 off on eBay Scott Scrivens View All Posts 2017/04/21 8:48am PDTApr 21, 2017 20 Plus 1 on G+ 46 Share on Facebook 37 Share on Twitter Total Shares103 Deals News Pixel It's no secret that Google has had some serious supply issues with its flagship Pixel phone. That goes for pretty much any combination of size, color, or storage. Rumors even began to surface alleging that¬†Google had stopped production of the devices altogether. That wasn't the case, but nonetheless, you will still struggle to actually find the Pixel if you wish to buy it.¬†A 32GB Pixel (international version) on eBay for $50 off the list price could be the answer to that problem. This is the entry level 5" Pixel, with 32GB of storage in the color Very Silver - and it's available for $599. That's $50 less than the $649 Google is still charging for it. Beware though, this is the international version of the device. So if you live in the US you'll have to check the bands to see if it works on your network. This version won't play nice with Verizon or Sprint, so if you're on either of those carriers you can rule this out. If you live outside the US then this is definitely for you. Shipping appears to be free in the US, but here in the UK, it's $18.99. That still works out a bargain for me, especially if you account for the exchange rate. You'll have to do the sums from where you are to see if the deal is as good for you. It's worth mentioning that getting your warranty honored might be tough with this type of purchase, so bear that in mind. It's hard to say how many of these they have, other than a "limited quantity," so you'll have to be quick if you want to get your hands on arguably the best Android phone of 2016. ¬† Home U.K. News Sports U.S. Showbiz Australia Femail Health Science Money Video Travel Columnists My Profile Logout Login Feedback DailyMail NEW ARTICLESHomeTop Share show ad Cyber kings destroying decency: As yet another appalling murder is streamed live, a leading writer warns we must fight the lawless billionaires of the net - or say goodbye to democracy and honesty for ever By Yasmin Alibhai-brown For The Mail On Sunday Published: 20:41 EDT, 29 April 2017 | Updated: 20:42 EDT, 29 April 2017 e-mail 17 shares 95 View comments What took them so long? When Facebook broadcast the horrific Thai murder of an 11-month-old baby, Natalie Jiranuch, hanged by her own father, it was a full 24 hours before the corporate giant removed the unspeakable video footage. By then it had been seen by 370,000 people, including the baby‚Äôs distraught mother, Jiranuch Trirat. Just a few days earlier, in Cleveland, Ohio, a pensioner called Robert Godwin was out collecting aluminium cans when Steve Stephens, 37, approached and shot him dead, muttering: ‚ÄòI‚Äôm about to kill this man right here, the old dude.‚Äô This killing was put on Facebook Live ‚Äì a murder which then remained visible to a supposedly civilised world for a full two hours. Mark Zuckerberg, pictured left, Google chief Eric Schmidt, pictured right, and others must be made to operate under the same tight rules and laws as newspapers, says Yasmin Alibhai-Brown And how did Facebook respond to these snuff videos and the torrent of justified criticism? By asking the rest of us, effectively, to do their job for them. ‚ÄòWe are reviewing flows to make sure people can report videos and other materials that violate our standards as easily and quickly as possible,‚Äô said a spokesman. ‚ÄòWe know we need to do better.‚Äô It does not take a tech expert to know that this was corporate bilge. The big beasts of new media believe they are untouchable and unaccountable. And this has to change. There is little that could match the brutality of these two on-line killings, yet they belong in a cesspit of appalling material that is freely available online. RELATED ARTICLES Previous 1 Next Yes, minister‚Ä¶ I AM surfing the net! Civil servants are... Facebook, Twitter and Google bosses will face personal fines... Share this article Share At its terrible worst it means terrorist slaughter, the torture of disabled people and young women, gang rapes, violent porn, child abuse, suicide and self-harm sites. Easily accessed, they are desensitising people, coarsening cultures, distorting values. Google lost millions of pounds last month when major companies pulled their advertising because their products were being promoted next to extremist YouTube videos. On that occasion, Google did act, and fast. Money counts, it seems. People do not. But online abuse is not confined to a world of murderous outrages. Instead it has seeped into an everyday existence in which trolls, for example, are free to be as intimidating and malicious as they please. Companies like Facebook, pictured, founded by Mark Zuckerberg, project themselves as the slick makers of a brave new world where old rules like financial and social integrity are pass√© (stock photo) Women and people of colour are viciously targeted. A friend of mine, a female Muslim local councillor, tried to kill herself after a particularly nasty week. In this virtual world there is no limit to the aggression hiding beneath a cloak of digital anonymity. Of course we cannot blame Twitter, Facebook or Google for everything. Degrading online material is a new, unprecedented problem that affects the internet as a whole. But the leading figures of the industry bear a particular responsibility. The men who took us into the jungle do nothing to civilize the space ‚Äì even though it is they who make the billions of pounds and dollars. Perhaps it is their very novelty which allows them to get away with it. Companies like Facebook, founded by Mark Zuckerberg, project themselves as the slick makers of a brave new world where old rules like financial and social integrity are pass√©. I have been to both Google and Facebook premises in London. When you enter, it is like passing the toughest border control, but once inside, you can only be impressed. These are delightful, intellectual playgrounds with hammocks, roof gardens and fabulous restaurants. It‚Äôs the strangest combination of secrecy and transparency, conformity and blue-sky thinking. And yes, these new corporations can be a force for good. The internet is an indispensable part of modern life. It has fast become as vital as fire, light, water and air. But those services, remember, are under some kind of state supervision. Google, pictured, lost millions of pounds last month when major companies pulled their advertising because their products were being promoted next to extremist YouTube videos (stock photo) Not so the controllers of the new, essential utility. They are lawless, hubristic, all powerful with businesses more profitable than any other sector has been through history. The most successful oil firms earn but hundreds of millions; Google, Facebook et al make billions. This is why the reprehensibly cold, nihilistic enterprises have put themselves above all laws, tax regimes and regulation. They are destroying government revenues and wilfully undermine democracies. Because they can. In his excellent report, Tech Giants And Civic Power, Martin Moore of King‚Äôs College, London, expresses grave concern at the erosion of citizen rights as ungovernable internet companies take over the universe. Yes, the internet can be an effective political tool for citizens who wish to hold the authorities to account ‚Äì in some circumstances. But remember this, too. Around the world, the internet is as likely to be used by governments to misinform or spy. In many respects, the internet wields the power of a broadcasting system ‚Äì but one without controls. Yasmin Alibhai-Brown says visiting the Google offices in London is 'like passing the toughest border control'. Pictured is the company's chief executive Eric Schmidt speaking in Hertfordshire in 2013 The most successful oil firms earn but hundreds of millions; Facebook et al make billions. Pictured is the social network's chief executive Mark Zuckerberg speaking at a conference in the US state of California earlier this month Truth itself and basic decency too have been corrupted by the tech companies. Now the carriers of fake news want to ‚Äòeducate‚Äô users so they can spot the lies and fabrications. Its just another planned, cynical, change-nothing strategy. Professor Gabriel Kahn, of the University of South California, warned last year that: ‚ÄòFacebook and Google are essentially polluting an information ecosystem with trash, with garbage, and it is clear that garbage has an impact.‚Äô This is everywhere. The internet is affecting impressionable people, children in particular. It is normalising sexual violence, encouraging discrimination and distorting elections. The big operators now own and manipulate nations, communities and families. They do so without any sense of social, economic, political or democratic responsibility. Zuckerberg, Google chief Eric Schmidt and others must be made to operate under the same tight rules and laws as newspapers and the traditional broadcast media. The internet giants have got away with too much for too long and have been contemptuous of fairness, accuracy, redress and consumer care ‚Äì all the principles of good journalism. Businesses which advertise on these sites must exert moral pressure too and more importantly, governments and international agencies must act to tame the cabal which has become a far bigger danger to humanity than any global conflict or megalomaniac leader. ¬† Share or comment on this article e-mail 17 shares Most watched News videos EXCLUSIVE: Woman in burka dragged off bus by undercover police Heineken ad brings together people who are 'worlds apart' Shocking video emerges of Delta Airlines pilot HITTING passenger Charlie Watkins' Take Me Out date filmed shortly before his death Calm cashier keeps his cool as armed robber threatens him with gun Harrowing footage shows Derry McCann stalking a woman Russian army tests remote controlled state-of-the-art tank Pack of killer whales attack mother gray whale and her calf Two women bloodied after fight over Brexit during UKIP campaign FLOTUS Trump dedicates a 'healing' garden at Children's National hospital Total wreckage in Afghanistan after MOAB strike destroys site Terrifying footage of a huge rhino chasing after a motorbike 'The best first date ever': Viewers left in tears as they... What We Use, 2017 Edition: The stuff Corbin can't live without Corbin Davenport Follow View All Posts 2017/04/28 8:26am PDTApr 28, 2017 11 Plus 1 on G+ 20 Share on Facebook 42 Share on Twitter Total Shares73 Features What We Use Series Article Contents 1 Hardware 1.0.1 Phone: Google Pixel 1.0.2 Tablet: Samsung Galaxy Tab S 8.4 1.0.3 Desktop PC: 'Enterprise' 1.0.4 Laptop: Dell Latitude 3340 ('Defiant') 1.0.5 Smartwatch: Huawei Watch (1st generation) 1.0.6 Camera: Sony Alpha a5000 1.0.7 Smart speaker: Google Home 1.0.8 Microphone: Blue Snowball iCE 1.0.9 Webcam: Logitech HD Pro C920 1.0.10 Charging dock: iKits 10-Port charging dock 2 Software 2.0.1 Sublime Text (Windows/Mac/Linux) 2.0.2 Signal Spy (Android) 2.0.3 InputMapper (Windows) 2.0.4 Chrome extensions (Windows/Mac/Linux) 3 Conclusion You may recall Android Police's long-running 'What We Use' series, where the fantastic people that work here share the tech (and sometimes non-tech) products they use on a frequent basis. I haven't actually written one of these posts yet - simply because I only joined AP last year.¬†I've had a fascination with technology as long as I can remember, but¬†my¬†arsenal of toys¬†is constantly changing. So without further ado, this is what I use. Hardware Phone: Google Pixel You may recall from my introduction post that¬†I was using a Nexus 5X. At the time, it was definitely the best phone I had ever used. The build quality was decent, but it was more than fast enough for my needs, the front-facing speakers were fantastic, and the camera was amazing. But all good things come to an end, and my 5X suffered the famous bootlooping bug that so many other 5X owners have¬†experienced. Being on Project Fi, and not really wanting to switch, I coughed up the money for a 32GB 5" Pixel. And while it has certainly been a great device and I would definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a fantastic Android phone, I still think it's overpriced. For those interested, I'm using the Unicorn Beetle Pro case. In addition to the Pixel, I also own a Microsoft Lumia 550 running Windows 10 Mobile. I bought it a few months before my 5X died (mostly to play around with Windows 10 Mobile), and it ended up being¬†my daily driver for roughly two weeks while I waited for my Pixel to ship. The lack of any Google services - especially Hangouts - means I can't really use it in place of an Android phone. But it does work just fine as a backup two-factor authentication device. Tablet: Samsung Galaxy Tab S 8.4 Most mainstream Android tablets hover around 9-10 inches, such as the Pixel C, the Tab S3, and the ASUS ZenPad I reviewed a while back. But I prefer 8.0-8.5"¬†tablets, leaving me with few options that weren't outdated. Currently, I'm using a Samsung Galaxy Tab S 8.4, and it's pretty great for what I need. Samsung has yet to update this to Nougat (and it will probably be a while), so I flashed LineageOS 14.1 on it. The Exynos 5420 processor does slow down occasionally, usually while multi-tasking or trying to play 1080p YouTube videos, but it's still plenty fast for most tasks. The Google Play Movies and Netflix apps don't play video at HD though - I assume because of some DRM restriction with Lineage. Desktop PC: 'Enterprise' My current desktop computer is my first custom-built PC, named 'Enterprise' (I name all of my computers after ships from Star Trek). It has an AMD Athlon X4 860k processor, Gigabyte GA-F2A68HM-H MicroATX motherboard, 420W EVGA power supply, and 16GB of RAM. I've recently upgraded my graphics card to an XFX Radeon RX 470. For storage, I have a 256GB boot SSD and a 1TB hard drive for storing games and backups. As for the rest of my setup, I'm using a simple Dell USB keyboard¬†with a Logitech G402 mouse. The keyboard is pretty nice, despite the low cost, and the mouse is quite comfortable.¬†I've just replaced my previous¬†dual-monitor setup (consisting of an old 1080p display and an ancient VGA monitor) with a¬†Dell U2913WM ultra-wide panel,¬†which has been fantastic so far. Seriously, playing games at ultrawide is amazing. Since originally building it last year, I've swapped out the original case for the¬†APEVIA X-QBER White enclosure, seen in the above picture. I'm not a fan of the windows, but I love that the case can flip open for easy access. Laptop: Dell Latitude 3340 ('Defiant') Before I decided to build my first computer (the PC in the last section), I had a Surface Pro 2 as my workstation. The concept of having one device to serve as my tablet, laptop, and desktop PC seemed great. I didn't even mind that it was a bit heavy - but I did mind the battery life. I'm not sure if it was Windows, the battery capacity, or the fact that I bought it used, but the Pro 2¬†would barely last a few hours on most days. I sold the Surface less than a year after I initially bought it, and decided to go with a normal boring laptop. My priorities were battery life, the ability to be upgraded, and durability - things my Surface Pro weren't very good at. I eventually stumbled upon a Dell Latitude 3340 for $200 on eBay, with a 13.3" 1366x768 display and a Core i5-4200U. Being a laptop designed for use in schools, it was pretty durable and almost every component could be replaced. I bought it, and spent another $100 swapping out the hard drive for a Samsung Evo 850 SSD and upgrading the RAM to 12GB. I also put a Stormtrooper decal on the back, because every laptop needs stickers. In short, I'm pretty happy with it. The laptop isn't thin by any means, but the battery life is solid and it's plenty fast for my needs. And after I replaced the spinning hard disk with an SSD, it has become dead silent (except during intense workloads). The resolution isn't great, but that's really my only complaint. Smartwatch: Huawei Watch (1st generation) Unlike some of the other writers here at Android Police, I still like the idea of smartwatches. I was an early adopter of Android Wear, and I loved diving into the underlying Android system. I bought a refurbished Huawei Watch a few months ago to replace my¬†original LG G Watch. I also own a first-gen Moto 360, which has unfortunately stopped working, and a Gear Live that needs a new watchband. Besides being a little thicker than I would like, the Huawei Watch is definitely a great¬†device. I don't really care that it's missing NFC or LTE, but I wouldn't mind the digital crown that some of the newer Android Wear watches have. Camera: Sony Alpha a5000 I know as much about cameras as I do cars - that is to say, not very much. Until I started working for AP, I had only used smartphones and sub-$50 digital cameras to take photos. So I consulted David to help pick a new camera, and I ended up with the Sony Alpha a5000. I've only had this camera for about a week, so I can't say much about it yet. It takes pictures. The a5000's Wi-Fi and NFC connectivity is especially cool - I can tap the camera to my Pixel and instantly transfer photos (which are then backed up to Google Photos). The Wi-Fi connectivity also allows me to remotely take photos with my phone as the viewfinder. I've used this several times already to take pictures of birds flying up to a nearby bird feeder. All of the photos in this post (except the picture of the camera) were taken on the a5000, so feel free to rage about my lack of photography skills leave constructive feedback in the comment section. Smart speaker: Google Home I initially bought a Google Home shortly after it was released, to replace an old set of iPod speakers I was using with a Chromecast Audio. I primarily use the Home as a wireless speaker, and it's pretty good at that. I don't really care for most smart home products, but I did buy¬†two WeMo¬†Smart Plugs on sale so I could control¬†two lamps in my room. Initially, these only worked through Google Assistant's IFTTT integration, but Google added native support for WeMo products a few months ago. I'll admit, the Google Home still seems half-baked. Most of my complaints about it from January are still valid, especially not being able to set reminders. I used the shopping list feature quite a bit, but Google basically ruined that. Microphone: Blue Snowball iCE I've been on the Android Police podcast for a while now, on a somewhat-infrequent basis (usually due to technical issues). My $11 headset I use for games wasn't really going to cut it, so I bought the Blue Snowball iCE condenser microphone. Overall, I'm pretty happy with it for the price.¬†The quality is very good and it's fairly portable. However, the microphone does occasionally disappear from Windows (I'm pretty sure that's Windows' fault), and the red light on the front is rather bright. As you can see in the above picture, I covered that up with some duct tape. Webcam: Logitech HD Pro C920 Another item I bought primarily for the AP Podcast was a webcam - Logitech's HD Pro C920 camera. In most cases, video calling is limited to 720p, but it can record and take photos at 1080p. Supposedly it works at 1080p with Skype for Windows, but I haven't tested that. Sample shot with the HD Pro C920. I don't really have any complaints about this webcam. It does webcam things. Charging dock: iKits 10-Port charging dock I have a ton of electronics that charge over USB. So a few months ago, I tried to become a bit more organized and replace my mess of charging adapters and cables with a single dock. After looking at a few on Amazon, I settled on iKit's 10-port charging dock. And it's seriously awesome. As you can see in the above picture, it has six normal 5V1A ports and four 5V2.4A ports.¬†With this, I can charge my tablet, phones, camera, and even my Nintendo DSi and 3DS (with this¬†cable).¬†The primary advantage is that the dock only needs one two-prong outlet, so you don't have to use separate wall adapters for every single device. If you have a bunch of products¬†that charge over USB, I definitely recommend this (or another dock like it). Software Most of the apps and programs I use on a daily basis are pretty popular. Chrome for browsing the web, Google Photos for image backups, Photoshop CS6 for photo editing, etc. That being said, there are a few apps/programs I use that you may not have heard of. Sublime Text (Windows/Mac/Linux) Sublime Text has been my main text editor for a few years now. Unlike Atom Editor and Visual Studio Code, it doesn't run inside a web shell, but still has plenty of plugins and themes. It supports auto-complete and syntax highlighting for dozens of languages,¬†so it's pretty versatile. I primarily use it when I'm working on Chrome extensions and Python scripts, and I don't think I've ever had a single problem. You can buy it for $70 from Sublime's site - the license works across platforms. Signal Spy (Android) ¬†¬† This is a pretty cool utility for Android, available on the Play Store for free (with a pro version available). It gives you information about the¬†carrier you are connected to, including the band being used and your signal strength. It also provides data about your Wi-Fi connection. If you're on Project Fi, as I am, Signal Spy has some extra functionality. As you may know, Project Fi switches between T-Mobile/US Cellular/Sprint based on who has the best signal. Occasionally, the switching algorithm doesn't work and leaves you with a poor connection. With Signal Spy, you can easily force a connection to a specific carrier (or re-enable auto switching). InputMapper (Windows) There are a few PC games that I use a controller for, such as Grand Theft Auto V. I actually prefer Sony's DualShock 4 controller over the Xbox 360 or Xbox One controllers, but very few PC games natively support the DS4. That's where InputMapper comes in. InputMapper is a small free utility that allows you to use a DualShock 4 controller with any game that supports Xbox controllers. It does this by emulating an Xinput device, and all the input from the DS4 is sent to the emulated controller. There is no loss in functionality, and you can use a DS4 over Bluetooth or USB. You can even remap buttons, as seen in the above screenshot. Chrome extensions (Windows/Mac/Linux) Lastly, I wanted to include a few Chrome extensions that I have found¬†extremely useful. Some of these are available on other browsers too. HTTPS Everywhere: This is an extension developed by the EFF that forces HTTPS on sites known to support it. Keepa: This adds a price history chart to Amazon listings. Privacy Badger: This is another extension from the EFF, which tries to block trackers online. Sometimes it can break certain sites, so if a web page won't work right for some reason, you probably need to turn this extension off. Peek: If you hover over a link to a file (or Google Doc), it will show a preview of it. It supports videos, audio files, PDFs, Office documents, and more. Full disclosure - I developed this one, but I think it's pretty darn useful. Save Image as PNG:¬†This adds a 'Save image as PNG' item to the right-click menu. Pretty simple. Toolbox for Google Play Store: This adds a few cool features to the Play Store web site, like a button on app listings to see APKs on APKMirror. It's actually developed by Android Police! Conclusion Wow, this post was long. If you¬†have any questions about the hardware or software in this list, feel free to ask me in the comments below. George Agreed to this as well, they are so comfortable to type on. The most important thing is to find the correct switch that suits you. Corbin Davenport I switch between this Dell keyboard and my mechanical keyboard from time to time, I just prefer the lower key travel on the Dell one (especially for gaming). ddevito I stopped reading at "Nexus 5X was the best phone I'd ever used" lol JK nice article Deeco DS4Windows is better no? someone755 I don't know how good it is with DS4 support, but for DS3, nothing beats SCP: https://github.com/nefarius/ScpToolkit Deeco Nice, but doesn't that lack customization? I use vim for configs and Sublime for coding when I need to edit many files at once, for Markdown, for random notes (because autosaving). Computator I use both depending on whether I am using a GUI or CLI. ghagiel Notepad++ or bust :-P jdrch I work in computer simulations, in which you can easily generate 2+GB text files for simulation inputs. Sublime Text is THE ONLY text editor that won't absolutely choke on those. Also, it seems to be the only (free) native 64-bit text editor for Windows. shadowx360 Same here. I work with massively parallel computational workloads that generate ridiculously large files that won't open in anything else that I've tried. Just turn off wordwrap on Sublime and it'll open them just fine even on my laptop. jdrch Nice to meet someone else in the industry haha. I usually get odd comments when I mention that I frequently wrangle 250K+ line text files üòÇüòÇ Jan-Lk Else What about adding HTTPS to AP? ;) Artem Russakovskii Yeah, working on it. Then, if you want to do your own later, you can, but people will be able to use https on the mean time. Artem Russakovskii We already do use Cloudflare, including their SSL, but it's not so simple with our setup for reasons I don't want to explain. We made it work on apkmirror already, and AP is coming. Simon I also bought a used Dell Latitude laptop. They're great. But it is a different model E7440 with 1080p, i5-4310u and ssd. I got lucky because the person selling it just got an updated battery with a bigger capacity from a newer model that still fits (without sticking out of the case). 8 hour battery life in a superb construction for 400CAD Bewear Hey, I've got the same webcam! I like it, though it seemed to have some problems while recording from non-Logitech software. You've got nice and interesting hardware. I was a bit surprised by that Samsung tablet, but then I noticed you were running LineageOS on it, that's great! makapav The Android tablet market is utter garbage and it's all Google's fault: apps running in phone mode, no decent 64-128GB options, ridiculous prices, no Android updates on most wifi tablets (I thought carriers were the cause of delayed OS updates on phones?), most tablet OEMs have stripped out multi-profile mode from their tablets...it's disappointing. I need two tablets but nothing that is remotely acceptable. Andr√©s Jabois Question about the microphone, what's the range at which you can talk to it without sounding too low? Corbin Davenport A few inches, maybe. I definitely have to keep it close. CaptainStarCone What watchface is that? Corbin Davenport https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.fatrussell.watchface.dinosaurwatchface JD Time to Ryzen up that desktop. Da Fuq Agreed, but it's gonna be pretty expensive. New CPU, MB and DDR4 RAM. JD Still cheaper than an Intel setup. Once you consider the performance gain you can't afford to not upgrade Mat√≠as Duarte DS4Windows works better for me than ImputMapper. It's already mapped and you can use the touchpad as a mouse. Pretty good for using your PC from distance. EDIT: nevermind, someone already posted this. Corbin Davenport InputMapper is already mapped too, and also lets you use the touchpad as a mouse. Peter Garlinski I like that USB dock. Do you use it charge the Pixel or any other USB C device? I'm thinking I would miss using USB C. Nice sticker by the way. I have a 'Stormtrooper' build going on my truck, but instead of a sticker, I went with a stormtrooper trailer hitch cover. Corbin Davenport Actually, I charge my Pixel with the stock charger next to my bedstand (the dock is in my closet, where I can easily hide the mess). This will work fine with USB Type-C devices if you use a Type A-to-C cable, but that won't work with USB-PD quick charging (maybe Qualcomm QC, not sure). jdrch Excellent setup. It's cool you can think for yourself instead of going for the standard Pixel XL + MBP/Chromebook like many Android blogdrones do. A few things: - Props on the desktop. Which OS do you use on it? - I swear by Sublime Text. Good call. - I didn't know LineageOS supported Galaxy Tab S models now, that's great news! I'm sick of my Shield K1's performance issues and am strongly considering dumping it for a Tab S/S2 running LOS. Corbin Davenport I use Windows 10 on all my PCs. I tried Fedora Linux a few weeks ago (I made a post about it on my personal blog: https://www.corbin.io/2017/04/trying-out-fedora-linux-part-one.html ), but booting into Windows every time I wanted to play a game wasn't really worth the hassle. jdrch More or less the same here. I run Windows 10 Release Ring on 2 Dell desktops and Slow Ring on a Vaio laptop. An ancient HP EliteBook runs Linux Mint (whatever the latest build is) just so I can keep up with what's going on in that world. Verizon Galaxy S5 running LOS 14.1 is my daily driver, and a stock unrooted (!!! it's sufficiently stock & supported well enough to make rooting and bootloader unlocking not that useful) Shield K1 is my tablet. I've always wanted to add a Mac or other BSD machine so I can say I run all 3 major desktop OSes, but so far it's been just too expensive to do (the new MBP prices haven't helped that situation,) I don't the space anyway, and administrating what I currently have is enough work as it is. I don't see the point or value of ChromeOS or Chromebooks when I can get a full blown laptop for approximately the same price. I should add: upgrade to the Logitech C922 or Brio 4K when you can. I upgraded to the latter (a couple weeks before Logitech sprang the Brio 4K release on me, I was so mad) and the picture quality upgrade is like night vs. day, not to mention the background replacement feature. Corbin Davenport I think (and I told people looking at Chromebooks when I worked at retail) that if you can get everything done in a browser, or with Android apps, Chromebooks are some of the best computers you can buy. Updates for years, no viruses/malware, speedy performance, and (mostly) cheap. Of course, the catch is having everything you need a browser. I can't, because I actively need Photoshop and a few developer tools that are non-existent on Chrome OS, but I think a lot of people can. Gen. Chang Interesting post, thanks for sharing. I'm curious though, how well the Project Fi has worked overall. Since you wanted to stick with it, I assume you get pretty good coverage and reception? But, how much data do you end up paying for? Is your bill consistently the same price each month? And have you experienced any of the Pixel backup issue's others have had? Corbin Davenport Project Fi has worked great. I'm not in a densely-populated area, so I never really deal with network congestion, and between Sprint and T-Mobile I rarely lose coverage. As far as the bill, it usually hovers between $30-40 each month for me. Not worrying about data caps and tethering restrictions is great, and syncing my calls/texts with Hangouts is icing on the cake. Regarding backups, the only thing that seems to be stuck is call history. abc Speaking of input mapper, Sony really should develop some official software to let their controllers work on PC. I don't get why they don't. It won't cost too much and will help them sell more controllers. Michael Hazell Must be nice to be able to afford expensive devices like the Pixel. I maintain my stance that there really hasn't been a successor to the OnePlus One since its inception because no future model has come to its price point. Amazon Tap firmware update enables Echo-style hands free voice commands Michael Crider Follow View All Posts 2017/02/09 6:03pm PDTFeb 9, 2017 6 Plus 1 on G+ 52 Share on Facebook 55 Share on Twitter Total Shares113 Accessories Amazon Here's an interesting example of a product getting better with age. The Amazon Tap speaker was introduced as a mobile, battery-powered alternative to the Echo, with access to the same Alexa voice commands, but limited in that it could only accept said commands with a button press. This made the less-expensive Tap, while interesting, not all that much better than a smartphone for voice searches. But the latest firmware update from Amazon enables hands-free Alexa commands, like the Echo and Google's Assistant on the Google Home. Talk about a value add. The new update can be downloaded and applied via the Amazon Alexa Android app. Once installed, the always-on voice feature can be turned on via the app whenever the speaker has a Wi-Fi connection available. The Tap should last for about 8 hours on a full charge even while always listening, and it can be put to sleep with a single button press when you're done with it. The new update actually makes the Amazon Tap something of a misnomer - tapping is no longer required. This new feature makes the Tap functionally identical to the Echo (albeit without some of the larger device's fancy omni-directional speaker tech) at a $50 discount and a much smaller form factor. For that matter, the $130 Amazon Tap is the same price as the Google Home, and comes with untethered battery use, too. Considering how much of a head start Amazon has on Google in the voice assistant gadget category, the new update can be seen as a savvy strike at the competition. Via: The Verge Tags alexa amazon amazon alexa amazon echo amazon tap firmware update subscribe ...
